Consent Form:
Are Visualizations About COVID-19 easy to understand?

 

Thank you for your interest in joining a study about COVID-19 visualizations. The study is being run by Carolina Nobre from Harvard University. This page provides some information about the research. 

 

What is the goal of this study?

 

The goal is to look at whether static and animated visualizations showing COVID-19 data are easy to understand. The results will be used to create better public health messaging about COVID-19 through visualizations. 

 

What can I expect if I take part in this research? 

 

Your participation is entirely up to you, and you may stop at any time. If you choose to take part, you will answer questions about COVID-19 visualizations. The survey will be online and should take around 20 minutes to finish.

 

For each visualization, you will be asked to answer questions that gauge your understanding of the visualization.  

 

 

You will be required to finish the whole survey in a SINGLE SITTING, with no distractions. If you need more time to finish the survey, you can choose to take longer than 20 minutes, but you may be timed out by Prolific after around  50 minutes.

 

When taking the survey, you will not have any contact with members of the study team. All information collected will be maintained anonymously. Names and other identifying information, such as IP addresses, will not be saved. 

 

What should I know about the research study?

 
Whether or not you take part is up to you. You can choose not to take part. You can agree to take part and later change your mind. Your decision will not be held against you.

 

Participants who score within the top 15% will receive a bonus pay so please fill this out as accurately as you can.

 

Who can I talk to? 

 

If you have questions, concerns, or a problem, please reach out to:

 

Carolina Nobre

Harvard Data Science Fellow

 

cnobre@seas.harvard.edu
Visual Literacy: How familiar are you with this type of visualization?
Understanding: How hard was it to understand this visualization?
Complexity: On a scale of 1 (not complex) to 5 (very complex), how complex did you find the visual design of this visualization?
Complexity - Unclear: What was unclear / hard to understand?
Animation: How helpful was the animation in understanding this visualization?
Animation - 2: Do you think you would have understood the visualization just as well without the animation?
Knowledge: How many hospitalizations per 100,000 people were there in Florida 2 weeks ago?
Comp - Summary: Describe what this data visualization tells you.
Comp - Takeaway: What would you say is the main takeaway?
Application: What is the difference in the number of hospitalizations over the last two weeks in Washington DC?
Analysis: How would you describe the trends in COVID 19 hospitalization over the last 2 weeks?
Synthesis AR: Given the hospitalization rates shown in the visualization, how might the number of hospitalized people change in Arkansas and in Rhode Island in the next 2 weeks?
Evaluation: Using evidence from this graph, describe measures that could help to reduce the number of COVID hospitalizations across the US. Make sure and explain how the graph informed your conclusions.
Knowledge 2: How many hospitalizations per 100,000 people were there in Missouri 2 weeks ago?
Trust: This visualization appeared in the New York Times on July 17 2021. On a scale of 1 (do not trust at all) to 5 (trust completely) , how much do you trust this visualization?

S4: Which best describes your race? Please choose as many options as apply. - Selected Choice
S4_6_TEXT: Which best describes your race? Please choose as many options as apply. - Another option not listed here (please specify): - Text
S5: What is your highest level of formal education?
S6: How would describe the area where you live?
S7: Generally speaking, which of the following best describes your political affiliation? - Selected Choice
S7_6_TEXT: Generally speaking, which of the following best describes your political affiliation? - Another option not listed here (please specify): - Text
S8: Thinking about your general approach to issues, do you consider yourself to be ________?
S9: How carefully did you complete this survey? Please answer honestly. Your payment does NOT depend on your response to this question.
S10: Thank you for participating in this pilot version of the study. We'd appreciate any feedback on the study. Did you have trouble understanding any of the questions? Did you like the animations? What were your overall impressions? Please let us know below!

Comp - Summary: States with higher vaccination rates typically see decreases in COVID-19 hospitalizations.
Analysis: Many states with lower vaccination rates are seeing increases in COVID-19 hospitalizations over the last two weeks.

Arkansas- strong increase so long as vaccination numbers remain low
Rhode Island- slight increase, but they are more successful with vaccination rates so the increase may not be stark as more people continue to get vaccinated

Consent Form: I understand the above information and consent to taking part in this study
Animation - 2: no, the animation made the data easier to understand.
Comp - Summary: it tells me that in certain states covid hospitalizations are increasing drastically and in other, not so much. in fact, there has been a decrease over the past 2 weeks in many states. it appears that those states with a greater percent of vaccinated peoples have a smaller degree of variability with the numbers, and more decreases in hospitalizations as well.
Comp - Takeaway: the main takeaway could be that vaccinations are effective against COVID
Analysis: if looking at all the states, there is no clear trend since some have increase hospitalizations while others have decreased. in general, there seems to be an increase where there is a smaller number of fully vaccinated individuals, and a decrease where there are more fully vaccinated.
Evaluation: measures include encouraging more people to get the vaccine and making it more accessible. additionally, masks should be encouraged or enforced where possible, especially in states where case are skyrocketing like Florida. we should think about what we were doing at the beginning - closing non essential businesses, only allowing carry out from restaurants, and encouraging outdoor gatherings only. these could all make a huge difference on the number of people getting sick.
Trust - Explanation: the data seems accurate with what I am hearing from other news outlets as well. the only reason i select a 4 instead of 5 is because there is always uncertainty with data and statistics, sometimes things can appear better/worse than they are.
S10: i think it was pretty good overall.

Consent Form: I understand the above information and consent to taking part in this study
Complexity - Unclear: It was hard for me to understand the difference between the arrows pointing up and down. I found it clear that in states with higher vaccination rates, the number of people hospitalized has gone down.
Animation - 2: no, the animation made the data easier to understand.
Comp - Summary: This visual shows how the number of people hospitalized has either gone up or down in the last 2 weeks and how the vaccination rates of each state impact the number of people hospitalized going up or down.
Comp - Takeaway: States with higher vaccination rates have seen lower numbers of people being hospitalized. Those states with lower vaccination rates are seeing either more hospitalizations or a lower decrease in hospitalizations than those states that have higher vaccination numbers.
Analysis: States with higher vaccination rates are going down and states with lower vaccination rates are going up or going down less.
Synthesis AR: In Arkansas, as vaccination rates go slightly up, their hospitalization numbers will likely go slightly down. In Rhode Island, as vaccination rates hit above 61%, their hospitalizations might begin the decline as opposed to rise.
Evaluation: By looking at this graph, I would say that if each state get's their populations over 61% vaccinated, they have a higher likelihood of their hospitalization numbers going down, As you can see on the graph, Maine, Massachusetts, and Vermont have over 61% vaccinated and their hospitalizations have proven to go down at this rate.
Trust - Explanation: I trust this visualization because it is in depth.
S10: I enjoyed this study because it had me working to see if I could put this image together. It also had me thinking about how images and graphics can sway someone to either believe or not believe in facts and numbers.
